content.webTitle: Jordan Spieth rues ‘dumb stuff’ as putting woes continue at Houston Open

fields.headline: Jordan Spieth rues ‘dumb stuff’ as putting woes continue at Houston Open
fields.bodyText: A dejected Jordan Spieth admitted one of his core strengths, putting, must dramatically improve if he is to launch a successful defence of the Masters next week. Spieth struggled on the greens throughout a second round of 73 at the Shell Houston Open, and the 22-year-old did little to mask his frustration. At four under par in total Spieth requires something extraordinary over the closing 36 holes if he is to head for Augusta National with the boost of a Texan victory. “I was really looking to gain some momentum today and kind of halted it instead,” Spieth said. “I have got to putt better. I’m losing a couple of strokes back to the field on putting and normally we’re gaining strokes. Inside 10 feet I have got to be solid and confident. “I can’t get into a rhythm. I’m stepping off putts. That’s a tough feeling and it kind of bleeds into the rest of your game, too, because you feel like you’ve got to be more aggressive. “So it really comes down to the putter for me. I have to get better before next week. I have got to get more comfortable, find a set-up position that I feel is going to produce the correct start lines.” Spieth further bemoaned “dumb stuff” such as two balls hit into water on par-fives on Friday, which triggered bogeys. “I’m going to be squeaking by the cut line and really far back from the lead,” he said. “So unfortunately it’s going to take something really special over the next 27 holes to even have a chance on the back nine on Sunday. I obviously would have liked to have more of a chance. “But it is what it is. I can only improve from here. There’s really nowhere to go but up on this weekend. I just need to find a higher comfort level with my putter and hopefully that leads to some mid-range putts going in plus some under-par rounds.” The Masters champion was at least spared the ignominy of a post-round penalty, after video analysis of an incident on the 5th green. Spieth clearly did not make a stroke at the ball when six inches from the hole but the matter was reassessed by rules officials. Spieth’s compatriot Rickie Fowler was in considerably more upbeat mood after a second round of 70 left him one better than Spieth with 36 holes to play. Fowler has endured a curiously low-key 2016 so far. “I’m excited,” said Fowler. “I haven’t had my best the last few days but I felt good out there. I have a couple of things to make some tweaks to and work on this weekend but definitely I like where my game is at going into next week.”
